1.verse: This is the vision Isaiah son of Amoz saw about what would happen to Judah and Jerusalem. Isaiah saw these things while Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were kings of Judah.

2.verse: God’s Case Against His Children - Heaven and earth, listen, because the LORD is speaking: “I raised my children and helped them grow up, but they have turned against me.

3.verse: An ox knows its master, and a donkey knows where its owner feeds it, but the people of Israel do not know me; my people do not understand.”

4.verse: How terrible! Israel is a nation of sin, a people loaded down with guilt, a group of children doing evil, children who are full of evil. They have left the LORD; they hate God, the Holy One of Israel, and have turned away from him as if he were a stranger.

5.verse: Why should you continue to be punished? Why do you continue to turn against him? Your whole head is hurt, and your whole heart is sick.

6.verse: There is no healthy spot from the bottom of your foot to the top of your head; you are covered with wounds, hurts, and open sores that are not cleaned and covered, and no medicine takes away the pain.

7.verse: Your land is ruined; your cities have been burned with fire. While you watch, your enemies are stealing everything from your land; it is ruined like a country destroyed by enemies.

8.verse: Jerusalem is left alone like an empty shelter in a vineyard, like a hut left in a field of melons, like a city surrounded by enemies.

9.verse: The LORD All-Powerful allowed a few of our people to live. Otherwise we would have been completely destroyed like the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah.

10.verse: Jerusalem, your rulers are like those of Sodom, and your people are like those of Gomorrah. Hear the word of the LORD; listen to the teaching of our God!

11.verse: The LORD says, “I do not want all these sacrifices. I have had enough of your burnt sacrifices of male sheep and fat from fine animals. I am not pleased by the blood of bulls, lambs, and goats.

12.verse: You come to meet with me, but who asked you to do all this running in and out of my Temple’s rooms?

13.verse: Don’t continue bringing me worthless sacrifices! I hate the incense you burn. I can’t stand your New Moons, Sabbaths, and other feast days; I can’t stand the evil you do in your holy meetings.

14.verse: I hate your New Moon feasts and your other yearly feasts. They have become a heavy weight on me, and I am tired of carrying it.

15.verse: When you raise your arms to me in prayer, I will refuse to look at you. Even if you say many prayers, I will not listen to you, because your hands are full of blood.

16.verse: Wash yourselves and make yourselves clean. Stop doing the evil things I see you do. Stop doing wrong.

17.verse: Learn to do good. Seek justice. Punish those who hurt others. Help the orphans. Stand up for the rights of widows.”

18.verse: The LORD says, “Come, let us talk about these things. Though your sins are like scarlet, they can be as white as snow. Though your sins are deep red, they can be white like wool.

19.verse: If you become willing and obey me, you will eat good crops from the land.

20.verse: But if you refuse to obey and if you turn against me, you will be destroyed by your enemies’ swords.” The LORD himself said these things.

21.verse: Jerusalem Is Not Loyal to God - The city of Jerusalem once followed the LORD, but she is no longer loyal to him. She used to be filled with fairness; people there lived the way God wanted. But now, murderers live there.

22.verse: Jerusalem, you have become like the scum left when silver is purified; you are like wine mixed with water.

23.verse: Your rulers are rebels and friends of thieves. They all accept money for doing wrong, and they are paid to cheat people. They don’t seek justice for the orphans or listen to the widows’ needs.

24.verse: So the Lord GOD All-Powerful, the Mighty One of Israel, says: “You, my enemies, will not cause me any more trouble. I will pay you back for what you did.

25.verse: I will turn against you and clean away all your wrongs as if with soap; I will take all the worthless things out of you.

26.verse: I will bring back judges as you had long ago; your counselors will be like those you had in the beginning. Then you will be called the City That Is Right with God, the Loyal City.”

27.verse: By doing what is fair, Jerusalem will be free again. By doing what is right, her people who come back to the LORD will have freedom.

28.verse: But sinners and those who turn against him will be destroyed; those who have left the LORD will die.

29.verse: “You will be ashamed, because you have worshiped gods under the oak trees. You will be disgraced, because you have worshiped idols in your gardens.

30.verse: You will be like an oak whose leaves are dying or like a garden without water.

31.verse: Powerful people will be like small, dry pieces of wood, and their works will be like sparks. They will burn together, and no one will be able to put out that fire.”

1.verse: The Message About Jerusalem - Isaiah son of Amoz saw this message about Judah and Jerusalem:

2.verse: In the last days the mountain on which the LORD’s Temple stands will become the most important of all mountains. It will be raised above the hills, and people from all nations will come streaming to it.

3.verse: Many nations will come and say, “Come, let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the Temple of the God of Jacob. Then God will teach us his ways, and we will obey his teachings.” His teachings will go out from Jerusalem; the message of the LORD will go out from Jerusalem.

4.verse: He will settle arguments among the nations and will make decisions for many nations. Then they will make their swords into plows and their spears into hooks for trimming trees. Nations will no longer fight other nations, nor will they train for war anymore.

5.verse: Come, family of Jacob, and let us follow the way of the LORD.

6.verse: A Terrible Day Is Coming - LORD, you have left your people, the family of Jacob, because they have become filled with wrong ideas from people in the East. They try to tell the future like the Philistines, and they have completely accepted those foreign ideas.

7.verse: Their land has been filled with silver and gold; there are a great many treasures there. Their land has been filled with horses; there are many chariots there.

8.verse: Their land is full of idols. The people worship these idols they made with their own hands and shaped with their own fingers.

9.verse: People will not be proud any longer but will bow low with shame. God, do not forgive them.

10.verse: Go into the caves of the cliffs; dig holes and hide in the ground from the anger of the LORD and from his great power!

11.verse: Proud people will be made humble, and they will bow low with shame. At that time only the LORD will still be praised.

12.verse: The LORD All-Powerful has a certain day planned when he will punish the proud and those who brag, and they will no longer be important.

13.verse: He will bring down the tall cedar trees from Lebanon and the great oak trees of Bashan,

14.verse: all the tall mountains and the high hills,

15.verse: every tall tower and every high, strong wall,

16.verse: all the trading ships and the beautiful ships.

17.verse: At that time proud people will be made humble, and they will bow low with shame. At that time only the LORD will be praised,

18.verse: but all the idols will be gone.

19.verse: People will run to caves in the rocky cliffs and will dig holes and hide in the ground from the anger of the LORD and his great power, when he stands to shake the earth.

20.verse: At that time people will throw away their gold and silver idols, which they made for themselves to worship; they will throw them away to the bats and moles.

21.verse: Then the people will hide in caves and cracks in the rocks from the anger of the LORD and his great power, when he stands to shake the earth.

22.verse: You should stop trusting in people to save you, because people are only human; they aren’t able to help you.

1.verse: God Will Punish Judah and Jerusalem - Understand this: The Lord GOD All-Powerful will take away everything Judah and Jerusalem need— all the food and water,

2.verse: the heroes and great soldiers, the judges and prophets, people who do magic and elders,

3.verse: the military leaders and government leaders, the counselors, the skilled craftsmen, and those who try to tell the future.

4.verse: The LORD says, “I will cause young boys to be your leaders, and foolish children will rule over you.

5.verse: People will be against each other; everyone will be against his neighbor. Young people will not respect older people, and common people will not respect important people.”

6.verse: At that time a man will grab one of his brothers from his own family and say, “You have a coat, so you will be our leader. These ruins will be under your control.”

7.verse: But that brother will stand up and say, “I cannot help you, because I do not have food or clothes in my house. You will not make me your leader.”

8.verse: This will happen because Jerusalem has stumbled, and Judah has fallen. The things they say and do are against the LORD; they turn against him.

9.verse: The look on their faces shows they are guilty; like the people of Sodom, they are proud of their sin. They don’t care who sees it. How terrible it will be for them, because they have brought much trouble on themselves.

10.verse: Tell those who do what is right that things will go well for them, because they will receive a reward for what they do.

11.verse: But how terrible it will be for the wicked! They will be punished for all the wrong they have done.

12.verse: Children treat my people cruelly, and women rule over them. My people, your guides lead you in the wrong way and turn you away from what is right.

13.verse: The LORD takes his place in court and stands to judge the people.

14.verse: The LORD presents his case against the elders and other leaders of his people: “You have burned the vineyard. Your houses are full of what you took from the poor.

15.verse: What gives you the right to crush my people and grind the faces of the poor into the dirt?” The Lord GOD All-Powerful says this.

16.verse: A Warning to Women of Jerusalem - The LORD says, “The women of Jerusalem are proud. They walk around with their heads held high, and they flirt with their eyes. They take quick, short steps, making noise with their ankle bracelets.”

17.verse: So the Lord will put sores on the heads of those women in Jerusalem, and he will make them lose their hair.

18.verse: At that time the Lord will take away everything that makes them proud: their beautiful ankle bracelets, their headbands, their necklaces shaped like the moon,

19.verse: their earrings, bracelets, and veils,

20.verse: their scarves, ankle chains, the cloth belts worn around their waists, their bottles of perfume, and charms,

21.verse: their signet rings, nose rings,

22.verse: their fine robes, capes, shawls, and purses,

23.verse: their mirrors, linen dresses, turbans, and long shawls.

24.verse: Instead of wearing sweet-smelling perfume, they will stink. Instead of fine cloth belts, they will wear the ropes of captives. Instead of having their hair fixed in fancy ways, they will be bald. Instead of fine clothes, they will wear clothes of sadness. Instead of being beautiful, they will wear the brand of a captive.

25.verse: At that time your men will be killed with swords, and your heroes will die in war.

26.verse: There will be crying and sadness near the city gates. Jerusalem will be like a woman who has lost everything and sits on the ground.

1.verse: At that time seven women will grab one man and say, “We will eat our own bread and make our own clothes, but please marry us! Please, take away our shame.”

2.verse: The Branch of the Lord - At that time the LORD’s branch will be very beautiful and great. The people still living in Israel will be proud of what the land grows.

3.verse: Those who are still living in Jerusalem will be called holy; their names are recorded among the living in Jerusalem.

4.verse: The Lord will wash away the filth from the women of Jerusalem. He will wash the bloodstains out of Jerusalem and clean the city with the spirit of fairness and the spirit of fire.

5.verse: Then the LORD will cover Mount Zion and the people who meet there with a cloud of smoke during the day and with a bright, flaming fire at night. There will be a covering over every person.

6.verse: This covering will protect the people from the heat of the sun and will provide a safe place to hide from the storm and rain.

1.verse: Israel, the Lord’s Vineyard - Now I will sing for my friend a song about his vineyard. My friend had a vineyard on a hill with very rich soil.

2.verse: He dug and cleared the field of stones and planted the best grapevines there. He built a tower in the middle of it and cut out a winepress as well. He hoped good grapes would grow there, but only bad ones grew.

3.verse: My friend says, “You people living in Jerusalem, and you people of Judah, judge between me and my vineyard.

4.verse: What more could I have done for my vineyard than I have already done? Although I expected good grapes to grow, why were there only bad ones?

5.verse: Now I will tell you what I will do to my vineyard: I will remove the hedge, and it will be burned. I will break down the stone wall, and it will be walked on.

6.verse: I will ruin my field. It will not be trimmed or hoed, and weeds and thorns will grow there. I will command the clouds not to rain on it.”

7.verse: The vineyard belonging to the LORD All-Powerful is the nation of Israel; the garden that he loves is the people of Judah. He looked for justice, but there was only killing. He hoped for right living, but there were only cries of pain.

8.verse: How terrible it will be for you who add more houses to your houses and more fields to your fields until there is no room left for other people. Then you are left alone in the land.

9.verse: The LORD All-Powerful said this to me: “The fine houses will be destroyed; the large and beautiful houses will be left empty.

10.verse: At that time a ten-acre vineyard will make only six gallons of wine, and ten bushels of seed will grow only half a bushel of grain.”

11.verse: How terrible it will be for people who rise early in the morning to look for strong drink, who stay awake late at night, becoming drunk with wine.

12.verse: At their parties they have lyres, harps, tambourines, flutes, and wine. They don’t see what the LORD has done or notice the work of his hands.

13.verse: So my people will be captured and taken away, because they don’t really know me. All the great people will die of hunger, and the common people will die of thirst.

14.verse: So the place of the dead wants more and more people, and it opens wide its mouth. Jerusalem’s important people and common people will go down into it, with their happy and noisy ones.

15.verse: So the common people and the great people will be brought down; those who are proud will be humbled.

16.verse: The LORD All-Powerful will receive glory by judging fairly; the holy God will show himself holy by doing what is right.

17.verse: Then the sheep will go anywhere they want, and lambs will feed on the land that rich people once owned.

18.verse: How terrible it will be for those people! They pull their guilt and sins behind them as people pull wagons with ropes.

19.verse: They say, “Let God hurry; let him do his work soon so we may see it. Let the plan of the Holy One of Israel happen soon so that we will know what it is.”

20.verse: How terrible it will be for people who call good things bad and bad things good, who think darkness is light and light is darkness, who think sour is sweet and sweet is sour.

21.verse: How terrible it will be for people who think they are wise and believe they are clever.

22.verse: How terrible it will be for people who are famous for drinking wine and are champions at mixing drinks.

23.verse: They take money to set the guilty free and don’t allow good people to be judged fairly.

24.verse: They will be destroyed just as fire burns straw or dry grass. They will be destroyed like a plant whose roots rot and whose flower dies and blows away like dust. They have refused to obey the teachings of the LORD All-Powerful and have hated the message from the Holy God of Israel.

25.verse: So the LORD has become very angry with his people, and he has raised his hand to punish them. Even the mountains are frightened. Dead bodies lie in the streets like garbage. But the LORD is still angry; his hand is still raised to strike down the people.

26.verse: He raises a banner for the nations far away. He whistles to call those people from the ends of the earth. Look! The enemy comes quickly!

27.verse: Not one of them becomes tired or falls down. Not one of them gets sleepy and falls asleep. Their weapons are close at hand, and their sandal straps are not broken.

28.verse: Their arrows are sharp, and all of their bows are ready to shoot. The horses’ hoofs are hard as rocks, and their chariot wheels move like a whirlwind.

29.verse: Their shout is like the roar of a lion; it is loud like a young lion. They growl as they grab their captives. There is no one to stop them from taking their captives away.

30.verse: On that day they will roar like the waves of the sea. And when people look at the land, they will see only darkness and pain; all light will become dark in this thick cloud.

1.verse: Isaiah Becomes a Prophet - In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a very high throne. His long robe filled the Temple.

2.verse: Heavenly creatures of fire stood above him. Each creature had six wings: It used two wings to cover its face, two wings to cover its feet, and two wings for flying.

3.verse: Each creature was calling to the others: “Holy, holy, holy is the LORD All-Powerful. His glory fills the whole earth.”

4.verse: Their calling caused the frame around the door to shake, as the Temple filled with smoke.

5.verse: I said, “Oh, no! I will be destroyed. I am not pure, and I live among people who are not pure, but I have seen the King, the LORD All-Powerful.”

6.verse: One of the heavenly creatures used a pair of tongs to take a hot coal from the altar. Then he flew to me with the hot coal in his hand.

7.verse: The creature touched my mouth with the hot coal and said, “Look, your guilt is taken away, because this hot coal has touched your lips. Your sin is taken away.”

8.verse: Then I heard the Lord’s voice, saying, “Whom can I send? Who will go for us?” So I said, “Here I am. Send me!”

9.verse: Then the Lord said, “Go and tell this to the people: ‘You will listen and listen, but you will not understand. You will look and look, but you will not learn.’

10.verse: Make the minds of these people dumb. Shut their ears. Cover their eyes. Otherwise, they might really understand what they see with their eyes and hear with their ears. They might really understand in their minds and come back to me and be healed.”

11.verse: Then I asked, “Lord, how long should I do this?” He answered, “Until the cities are destroyed and the people are gone, until there are no people left in the houses, until the land is destroyed and left empty.

12.verse: The LORD will send the people far away, and the land will be left empty.

13.verse: One-tenth of the people will be left in the land, but it will be destroyed again. These people will be like an oak tree whose stump is left when the tree is chopped down. The people who remain will be like a stump that will sprout again.”

1.verse: Trouble with Aram - Now Ahaz was the son of Jotham, who was the son of Uzziah. When Ahaz was king of Judah, Rezin king of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah, the king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to fight against it. But they were not able to defeat the city.

2.verse: Ahaz king of Judah received a message saying, “The armies of Aram and Israel have joined together.” When Ahaz heard this, he and the people were frightened. They shook with fear like trees of the forest blown by the wind.

3.verse: Then the LORD told Isaiah, “You and your son Shear-Jashub should go and meet Ahaz at the place where the water flows into the upper pool, on the road where people do their laundry.

4.verse: Tell Ahaz, ‘Be careful. Be calm and don’t worry. Don’t let those two men, Rezin and Pekah son of Remaliah, scare you. Don’t be afraid of their anger or Aram’s anger, because they are like two barely burning sticks that are ready to go out.

5.verse: They have made plans against you, saying,

6.verse: “Let’s fight against Judah and tear it apart. We will divide the land for ourselves and make the son of Tabeel the new king of Judah.”

7.verse: But I, the Lord GOD, say, “‘Their plan will not succeed; it will not happen,

8.verse: because Aram is led by the city of Damascus, and Damascus is led by its weak king, Rezin. Within sixty-five years Israel will no longer be a nation.

9.verse: Israel is led by the city of Samaria, and Samaria is led by its weak king, the son of Remaliah. If your faith is not strong, you will not have strength enough to last.’”

10.verse: Immanuel—God Is with Us - Then the LORD spoke to Ahaz again, saying,

11.verse: “Ask for a sign from the LORD your God to prove to yourself that these things are true. It may be a sign from as deep as the place of the dead or as high as the heavens.”

12.verse: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask for a sign or test the LORD.”

13.verse: Then Isaiah said, “Ahaz, descendant of David, listen carefully! Isn’t it bad enough that you wear out the patience of people? Do you also have to wear out the patience of my God?

14.verse: The Lord himself will give you a sign: The virgin will be pregnant. She will have a son, and she will name him Immanuel.

15.verse: He will be eating milk curds and honey when he learns to reject what is evil and to choose what is good.

16.verse: You are afraid of the kings of Israel and Aram now. But before the child learns to choose good and reject evil, the lands of Israel and Aram will be empty.

17.verse: The LORD will bring troubled times to you, your people, and to the people of your father’s family. They will be worse than anything that has happened since Israel separated from Judah. The LORD will bring the king of Assyria to fight against you.

18.verse: “At that time the LORD will whistle for the Egyptians, and they will come like flies from Egypt’s faraway streams. He will call for the Assyrians, and they will come like bees.

19.verse: These enemies will camp in the deep ravines and in the cliffs, by the thornbushes and watering holes.

20.verse: The Lord will hire Assyria and use it like a razor to punish Judah. It will be as if the Lord is shaving the hair from Judah’s head and legs and removing Judah’s beard.

21.verse: “At that time a person will be able to keep only one young cow and two sheep alive.

22.verse: There will be only enough milk for that person to eat milk curds. All who remain in the land will go back to eating just milk curds and honey.

23.verse: In this land there are now vineyards that have a thousand grapevines, which are worth about twenty-five pounds of silver. But these fields will become full of weeds and thorns.

24.verse: The land will become wild and useful only as a hunting ground.

25.verse: People once worked and grew food on these hills, but at that time people will not go there, because the land will be filled with weeds and thorns. Only sheep and cattle will go to those places.”

1.verse: Assyria Will Come Soon - The LORD told me, “Take a large scroll and write on it with an ordinary pen: ‘Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.’

2.verse: I will gather some men to be reliable witnesses: Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberekiah.”

3.verse: Then I went to the prophetess, and she became pregnant and had a son. The LORD told me, “Name the boy Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz,

4.verse: because the king of Assyria will take away all the wealth and possessions of Damascus and Samaria before the boy learns to say ‘my father’ or ‘my mother.’”

5.verse: Again the LORD spoke to me, saying,

6.verse: “These people refuse to accept the slow-moving waters of the pool of Shiloah and are terrified of Rezin and Pekah son of Remaliah.

7.verse: So I, the Lord, will bring the king of Assyria and all his power against them, like a powerful flood of water from the Euphrates River. The Assyrians will be like water rising over the banks of the river, flowing over the land.

8.verse: That water will flow into Judah and pass through it, rising to Judah’s throat. Immanuel, this army will spread its wings like a bird until it covers your whole country.”

9.verse: Be broken, all you nations, and be smashed to pieces. Listen, all you faraway countries. Prepare for battle and be smashed to pieces! Prepare for battle and be smashed to pieces!

10.verse: Make your plans for the fight, but they will be defeated. Give orders to your armies, but they will be useless, because God is with us.

11.verse: Warnings to Isaiah - The LORD spoke to me with his great power and warned me not to follow the lead of the rest of the people. He said,

12.verse: “People are saying that others make plans against them, but you should not believe them. Don’t be afraid of what they fear; do not dread those things.

13.verse: But remember that the LORD All-Powerful is holy. He is the one you should fear; he is the one you should dread.

14.verse: Then he will be a place of safety for you. But for the two families of Israel, he will be like a stone that causes people to stumble, like a rock that makes them fall. He will be like a trap for the people of Jerusalem, and he will catch them in his trap.

15.verse: Many people will fall over this rock. They will fall and be broken; they will be trapped and caught.”

16.verse: Make an agreement. Seal up the teaching while my followers are watching.

17.verse: I will wait for the LORD to help us, the LORD who is ashamed of the family of Israel. I will wait for him.

18.verse: I am here, and with me are the children the LORD has given me. We are signs and proofs for the people of Israel from the LORD All-Powerful, who lives on Mount Zion.

19.verse: Some people say, “Ask the mediums and fortune-tellers, who whisper and mutter, what to do.” But I tell you that people should ask their God for help. Why should people who are still alive ask something from the dead?

20.verse: You should follow the teachings and the agreement with the LORD. The mediums and fortune-tellers do not speak the word of the LORD, so their words are worth nothing.

21.verse: People will wander through the land troubled and hungry. When they become hungry, they will become angry and will look up and curse their king and their God.

22.verse: They will look around them at their land and see only trouble, darkness, and awful gloom. And they will be forced into the darkness.

1.verse: A New Day Is Coming - But suddenly there will be no more gloom for the land that suffered. In the past God made the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali hang their heads in shame, but in the future those lands will be made great. They will stretch from the road along the Mediterranean Sea to the land beyond the Jordan River and north to Galilee, the land of people who are not Israelites.

2.verse: Before those people lived in darkness, but now they have seen a great light. They lived in a dark land, but a light has shined on them.

3.verse: God, you have caused the nation to grow and made the people happy. And they have shown their happiness to you, like the joy during harvest time, like the joy of people taking what they have won in war.

4.verse: Like the time you defeated Midian, you have taken away their heavy load and the heavy pole from their backs and the rod the enemy used to punish them.

5.verse: Every boot that marched in battle and every uniform stained with blood has been thrown into the fire.

6.verse: A child has been born to us; God has given a son to us. He will be responsible for leading the people. His name will be Wonderful Counselor, Powerful God, Father Who Lives Forever, Prince of Peace.

7.verse: Power and peace will be in his kingdom and will continue to grow forever. He will rule as king on David’s throne and over David’s kingdom. He will make it strong by ruling with justice and goodness from now on and forever. The LORD All-Powerful will do this because of his strong love for his people.

8.verse: God Will Punish Israel - The Lord sent a message against the people of Jacob; it says that God will judge Israel.

9.verse: Then everyone in Israel, even the leaders in Samaria, will know that God has sent it. Those people are proud and brag by saying,

10.verse: “These bricks have fallen, but we will build again with cut stones. These small trees have been chopped down, but we will put great cedars there.”

11.verse: But the LORD has brought the enemies of Rezin against them; he has stirred up their enemies against them.

12.verse: The Arameans came from the east and the Philistines from the west, and they ate up Israel with their armies. But the LORD was still angry; his hand was still raised to punish the people.

13.verse: But the people did not return to the one who had struck them; they did not follow the LORD All-Powerful.

14.verse: So the LORD cut off Israel’s head and tail, taking away both the branch and stalk in one day.

15.verse: The elders and important men were the head, and the prophets who speak lies were the tail.

16.verse: Those who led the people led them in the wrong direction, and those who followed them were destroyed.

17.verse: So the Lord is not happy with the young people, nor will he show mercy to the orphans and widows. All the people are separated from God and are very evil; they all speak lies. But the LORD is still angry; his hand is still raised to strike down the people.

18.verse: Evil is like a small fire. First, it burns weeds and thorns. Next, it burns the larger bushes in the forest, and they all go up in a column of smoke.

19.verse: The LORD All-Powerful is angry, so the land will be burned. The people are like fuel for the fire; no one will try to save his brother or sister.

20.verse: People will grab something on the right, but they will still be hungry. They will eat something on the left, but they will not be filled. Then they will each turn and eat their own children.

21.verse: The people of Manasseh will fight against the people of Ephraim, and Ephraim will fight against Manasseh. Then both of them will turn against Judah. But the LORD is still angry; his hand is still raised to strike down the people.

1.verse: How terrible it will be for those who make unfair laws, and those who write laws that make life hard for people.

2.verse: They are not fair to the poor, and they rob my people of their rights. They allow people to steal from widows and to take from orphans what really belongs to them.

3.verse: How will you explain the things you have done? What will you do when your destruction comes from far away? Where will you run for help? Where will you hide your riches then?

4.verse: You will have to bow down among the captives or fall down among the dead bodies. But the LORD is still angry; his hand is still raised to strike down the people.

5.verse: God Will Punish Assyria - God says, “How terrible it will be for the king of Assyria. I use him like a rod to show my anger; in anger I use Assyria like a club.

6.verse: I send it to fight against a nation that is separated from God. I am angry with those people, so I command Assyria to fight against them, to take their wealth from them, to trample them down like dirt in the streets.

7.verse: But Assyria’s king doesn’t understand that I am using him; he doesn’t know he is a tool for me. He only wants to destroy other people and to defeat many nations.

8.verse: The king of Assyria says to himself, ‘All of my commanders are like kings.

9.verse: The city Calno is like the city Carchemish. The city Hamath is like the city Arpad. The city Samaria is like the city Damascus.

10.verse: I defeated those kingdoms that worship idols, and those idols were more than the idols of Jerusalem and Samaria.

11.verse: As I defeated Samaria and her idols, I will also defeat Jerusalem and her idols.’”

12.verse: When the Lord finishes doing what he planned to Mount Zion and Jerusalem, he will punish Assyria. The king of Assyria is very proud, and his pride has made him do these evil things, so God will punish him.

13.verse: The king of Assyria says this: “By my own power I have done these things; by my wisdom I have defeated many nations. I have taken their wealth, and, like a mighty one, I have taken their people.

14.verse: I have taken the riches of all these people, like a person reaching into a bird’s nest. I have taken these nations, like a person taking eggs. Not one raised a hand or opened its mouth to stop me.”

15.verse: An ax is not better than the person who swings it. A saw is not better than the one who uses it. A stick cannot control the person who picks it up. A club cannot pick up the person!

16.verse: So the Lord GOD All-Powerful will send a terrible disease upon Assyria’s soldiers. The strength of Assyria will be burned up like a fire burning until everything is gone.

17.verse: God, the Light of Israel, will be like a fire; the Holy One will be like a flame. He will be like a fire that suddenly burns the weeds and thorns.

18.verse: The fire burns away the great trees and rich farmlands, destroying everything. It will be like a sick person who wastes away.

19.verse: The trees left standing will be so few that even a child could count them.

20.verse: At that time some people will be left alive in Israel from the family of Jacob. They will not continue to depend on the person who defeated them. They will learn truly to depend on the LORD, the Holy One of Israel.

21.verse: Those who are left alive in Jacob’s family will again follow the powerful God.

22.verse: Israel, your people are many, like the grains of sand by the sea. But only a few of them will be left alive to return to the LORD. God has announced that he will destroy the land completely and fairly.

23.verse: The Lord GOD All-Powerful will certainly destroy this land, as he has announced.

24.verse: This is what the Lord GOD All-Powerful says: “My people living in Jerusalem, don’t be afraid of the Assyrians, who beat you with a rod and raise a stick against you, as Egypt did.

25.verse: After a short time my anger against you will stop, and then I will turn my anger to destroying them.”

26.verse: Then the LORD All-Powerful will beat the Assyrians with a whip as he defeated Midian at the rock of Oreb. He will raise his stick over the waters as he did in Egypt.

27.verse: Then the troubles that Assyria puts on you will be removed, and the load they make you carry will be taken away.

28.verse: Assyria Invades Israel - The army of Assyria will enter near Aiath. Its soldiers will walk through Migron. They will store their food in Micmash.

29.verse: The army will go over the pass. The soldiers will sleep at Geba. The people of Ramah will be afraid, and the people at Gibeah of Saul will run away.

30.verse: Cry out, Bath Gallim! Laishah, listen! Poor Anathoth!

31.verse: The people of Madmenah are running away; the people of Gebim are hiding.

32.verse: This day the army will stop at Nob. They will shake their fist at Mount Zion, at the hill of Jerusalem.

33.verse: Watch! The Lord GOD All-Powerful with his great power will chop them down like a great tree. Those who are great will be cut down; those who are important will fall to the ground.

34.verse: He will cut them down as a forest is cut down with an ax. And the great trees of Lebanon will fall by the power of the Mighty One.

1.verse: The King of Peace Is Coming - A new branch will grow from a stump of a tree; so a new king will come from the family of Jesse.

2.verse: The Spirit of the LORD will rest upon that king. The Spirit will give him wisdom and understanding, guidance and power. The Spirit will teach him to know and respect the LORD.

3.verse: This king will be glad to obey the LORD. He will not judge by the way things look or decide by what he hears.

4.verse: But he will judge the poor honestly; he will be fair in his decisions for the poor people of the land. At his command evil people will be punished, and by his words the wicked will be put to death.

5.verse: Goodness and fairness will give him strength, like a belt around his waist.

6.verse: Then wolves will live in peace with lambs, and leopards will lie down to rest with goats. Calves, lions, and young bulls will eat together, and a little child will lead them.

7.verse: Cows and bears will eat together in peace. Their young will lie down to rest together. Lions will eat hay as oxen do.

8.verse: A baby will be able to play near a cobra’s hole, and a child will be able to put his hand into the nest of a poisonous snake.

9.verse: They will not hurt or destroy each other on all my holy mountain, because the earth will be full of the knowledge of the LORD, as the sea is full of water.

10.verse: At that time the new king from the family of Jesse will stand as a banner for all peoples. The nations will come together around him, and the place where he lives will be filled with glory.

11.verse: At that time the Lord will again reach out and take his people who are left alive in Assyria, North Egypt, South Egypt, Cush, Elam, Babylonia, Hamath, and all the islands of the sea.

12.verse: God will raise a banner as a sign for all nations, and he will gather the people of Israel who were forced from their country. He will gather the scattered people of Judah from all parts of the earth.

13.verse: At that time Israel will not be jealous anymore, and Judah will have no more enemies. Israel will not be jealous of Judah, and Judah will not hate Israel.

14.verse: But Israel and Judah will attack the Philistines on the west. Together they will take the riches from the people of the east. They will conquer Edom and Moab, and the people of Ammon will be under their control.

15.verse: The LORD will dry up the Red Sea of Egypt. He will wave his arm over the Euphrates River and dry it up with a scorching wind. He will divide it into seven small rivers so that people can walk across them with their sandals on.

16.verse: So God’s people who are left alive will have a way to leave Assyria, just like the time the Israelites came out of Egypt.

1.verse: A Song of Praise to God - At that time you will say: “I praise you, LORD! You were angry with me, but you are not angry with me now! You have comforted me.

2.verse: God is the one who saves me; I will trust him and not be afraid. The LORD, the LORD gives me strength and makes me sing. He has saved me.”

3.verse: You will receive your salvation with joy as you would draw water from a well.

4.verse: At that time you will say, “Praise the LORD and worship him. Tell everyone what he has done and how great he is.

5.verse: Sing praise to the LORD, because he has done great things. Let all the world know what he has done.

6.verse: Shout and sing for joy, you people of Jerusalem, because the Holy One of Israel does great things before your eyes.”

1.verse: God’s Message to Babylon - God showed Isaiah son of Amoz this message about Babylon:

2.verse: Raise a flag on the bare mountain. Call out to the men. Raise your hand to signal them to enter through the gates for important people.

3.verse: I myself have commanded those people whom I have separated as mine. I have called those warriors to carry out my anger. They rejoice and are glad to do my will.

4.verse: Listen to the loud noise in the mountains, the sound of many people. Listen to the noise among the kingdoms, the sound of nations gathering together. The LORD All-Powerful is calling his army together for battle.

5.verse: This army is coming from a faraway land, from the edge of the horizon. In anger the LORD is using this army like a weapon to destroy the whole country.

6.verse: Cry, because the LORD’s day of judging is near; the Almighty is sending destruction.

7.verse: People will be weak with fear, and their courage will melt away.

8.verse: Everyone will be afraid. Pain and hurt will grab them; they will hurt like a woman giving birth to a baby. They will look at each other in fear, with their faces red like fire.

9.verse: God’s Judgment Against Babylon - Look, the LORD’s day of judging is coming— a terrible day, a day of God’s anger. He will destroy the land and the sinners who live in it.

10.verse: The stars will not show their light; the skies will be dark. The sun will grow dark as it rises, and the moon will not give its light.

11.verse: The LORD says, “I will punish the world for its evil and wicked people for their sins. I will cause proud people to lose their pride, and I will destroy the pride of those who are cruel to others.

12.verse: People will be harder to find than pure gold; there will be fewer people than there is fine gold in Ophir.

13.verse: I will make the sky shake, and the earth will be moved from its place by the anger of the LORD All-Powerful at the time of his burning anger.

14.verse: “Then the people from Babylon will run away like hunted deer or like sheep who have no shepherd. Everyone will turn back to his own people; each will run back to his own land.

15.verse: Everyone who is captured will be killed; everyone who is caught will be killed with a sword.

16.verse: Their little children will be beaten to death in front of them. Their houses will be robbed and their wives raped.

17.verse: “Look, I will cause the armies of Media to attack Babylon. They do not care about silver or delight in gold.

18.verse: Their soldiers will shoot the young men with arrows; they will show no mercy on children, nor will they feel sorry for little ones.

19.verse: Babylon is the most beautiful of all kingdoms, and the Babylonians are very proud of it. But God will destroy it like Sodom and Gomorrah.

20.verse: No one will ever live there or settle there again. No Arab will put a tent there; no shepherd will bring sheep there.

21.verse: Only desert animals will live there, and their houses will be full of wild dogs. Owls will live there, and wild goats will leap about in the houses.

22.verse: Wolves will howl within the strong walls, and wild dogs will bark in the beautiful buildings. The end of Babylon is near; its time is almost over.”

1.verse: Israel Will Return Home - The LORD will show mercy to the people of Jacob, and he will again choose the people of Israel. He will settle them in their own land. Then non-Israelite people will join the Israelites and will become a part of the family of Jacob.

2.verse: Nations will take the Israelites back to their land. Then those men and women from the other nations will become slaves to Israel in the LORD’s land. In the past the Israelites were their slaves, but now the Israelites will defeat those nations and rule over them.

3.verse: The King of Babylon Will Fall - The LORD will take away the Israelites’ hard work and will comfort them. They will no longer have to work hard as slaves.

4.verse: On that day Israel will sing this song about the king of Babylon: The cruel king who ruled us is finished; his angry rule is finished!

5.verse: The LORD has broken the scepter of evil rulers and taken away their power.

6.verse: The king of Babylon struck people in anger again and again. He ruled nations in anger and continued to hurt them.

7.verse: But now, the whole world rests and is quiet. Now the people begin to sing.

8.verse: Even the pine trees are happy, and the cedar trees of Lebanon rejoice. They say, “The king has fallen, so no one will ever cut us down again.”

9.verse: The place of the dead is excited to meet you when you come. It wakes the spirits of the dead, the leaders of the world. It makes kings of all nations stand up from their thrones to greet you.

10.verse: All these leaders will make fun of you and will say, “Now you are weak, as we are. Now you are just like us.”

11.verse: Your pride has been sent down to the place of the dead. The music from your harps goes with it. Flies are spread out like your bed beneath you, and worms cover your body like a blanket.

12.verse: King of Babylon, morning star, you have fallen from heaven, even though you were as bright as the rising sun! In the past all the nations on earth bowed down before you, but now you have been cut down.

13.verse: You told yourself, “I will go up to heaven. I will put my throne above God’s stars. I will sit on the mountain of the gods, on the slopes of the sacred mountain.

14.verse: I will go up above the tops of the clouds. I will be like God Most High.”

15.verse: But you were brought down to the grave, to the deep places where the dead are.

16.verse: Those who see you stare at you. They think about what has happened to you and say, “Is this the same man who caused great fear on earth, who shook the kingdoms,

17.verse: who turned the world into a desert, who destroyed its cities, who captured people in war and would not let them go home?”

18.verse: Every king of the earth has been buried with honor, each in his own grave.

19.verse: But you are thrown out of your grave, like an unwanted branch. You are covered by bodies that died in battle, by bodies to be buried in a rocky pit. You are like a dead body other soldiers walk on.

20.verse: You will not be buried with those bodies, because you ruined your own country and killed your own people. The children of evil people will never be mentioned again.

21.verse: Prepare to kill his children, because their father is guilty. They will never again take control of the earth; they will never again fill the world with their cities.

22.verse: The LORD All-Powerful says this: “I will fight against those people; I will destroy Babylon and its people, its children and their descendants,” says the LORD.

23.verse: “I will make Babylon fit only for owls and for swamps. I will sweep Babylon as with a broom of destruction,” says the LORD All-Powerful.

24.verse: God Will Punish Assyria - The LORD All-Powerful has made this promise: “These things will happen exactly as I planned them; they will happen exactly as I set them up.

25.verse: I will destroy the king of Assyria in my country; I will trample him on my mountains. He placed a heavy load on my people, but that weight will be removed.

26.verse: “This is what I plan to do for all the earth. And this is the hand that I have raised over all nations.”

27.verse: When the LORD All-Powerful makes a plan, no one can stop it. When the LORD raises his hand to punish people, no one can stop it.

28.verse: God’s Message to Philistia - This message was given in the year that King Ahaz died:

29.verse: Country of Philistia, don’t be happy that the king who struck you is now dead. He is like a snake that will give birth to another dangerous snake. The new king will be like a quick, dangerous snake to bite you.

30.verse: Even the poorest of my people will be able to eat safely, and people in need will be able to lie down in safety. But I will kill your family with hunger, and all your people who are left will die.

31.verse: People near the city gates, cry out! Philistines, be frightened, because a cloud of dust comes from the north. It is an army, full of men ready to fight.

32.verse: What shall we tell the messengers from Philistia? Say that the LORD has made Jerusalem strong and that his poor people will go there for safety.

1.verse: God’s Message to Moab - This is a message about Moab: In one night armies took the wealth from Ar in Moab, and it was destroyed. In one night armies took the wealth from Kir in Moab, and it was destroyed.

2.verse: The people of Dibon go to the places of worship to cry. The people of Moab cry for the cities of Nebo and Medeba. Every head and beard has been shaved to show how sad Moab is.

3.verse: In the streets they wear rough cloth to show their sadness. On the roofs and in the public squares, they are crying loudly.

4.verse: People in the cities Heshbon and Elealeh cry out loud. You can hear their voices far away in the city Jahaz. Even the soldiers are frightened; they are shaking with fear.

5.verse: My heart cries with sorrow for Moab. Its people run away to Zoar for safety; they run to Eglath Shelishiyah. People are going up the mountain road to Luhith, crying as they go. People are going on the road to Horonaim, crying over their destruction.

6.verse: But the water of Nimrim has dried up. The grass has dried up, and all the plants are dead; nothing green is left.

7.verse: So the people gather up what they have saved and carry it across the Ravine of the Poplars.

8.verse: Crying is heard everywhere in Moab. Their crying is heard as far away as the city Eglaim; it is heard as far away as Beer Elim.

9.verse: The water of the city Dibon is full of blood, and I, the LORD, will bring even more troubles to Dibon. A few people living in Moab have escaped the enemy, but I will send lions to kill them.

1.verse: Send the king of the land the payment he demands. Send a lamb from Sela through the desert to the mountain of Jerusalem.

2.verse: The women of Moab try to cross the river Arnon like little birds that have fallen from their nest.

3.verse: They say: “Help us. Tell us what to do. Protect us from our enemies as shade protects us from the noon sun. Hide us, because we are running for safety! Don’t give us to our enemies.

4.verse: Let those of us who were forced out of Moab live in your land. Hide us from our enemies.” The robbing of Moab will stop. The enemy will be defeated; those who hurt others will disappear from the land.

5.verse: Then a new loyal king will come; this faithful king will be from the family of David. He will judge fairly and do what is right.

6.verse: We have heard that the people of Moab are proud and very conceited. They are very proud and angry, but their bragging means nothing.

7.verse: So the people of Moab will cry; they will all be sad. They will moan and groan for the raisin cakes they had in Kir Hareseth.

8.verse: But the fields of Heshbon and the vines of Sibmah cannot grow grapes; foreign rulers have destroyed the grapevines. The grapevines once spread as far as the city of Jazer and into the desert; they had spread as far as the sea.

9.verse: I cry with the people of Jazer for the grapevines of Sibmah. I will cry with the people of Heshbon and Elealeh. There will be no shouts of joy, because there will be no harvest or ripe fruit.

10.verse: There will be no joy and happiness in the orchards and no songs or shouts of joy in the vineyards. No one makes wine in the winepresses, because I have put an end to shouts of joy.

11.verse: My heart cries for Moab like a harp playing a funeral song; I am very sad for Kir Hareseth.

12.verse: The people of Moab will go to their places of worship and will try to pray. But when they go to their temple to pray, they will not be able.

13.verse: Earlier the LORD said these things about Moab.

14.verse: Now the LORD says, “In three years all those people and what they take pride in will be hated. (This is three years as a hired helper would count time.) There will be a few people left, but they will be weak.”

1.verse: God’s Message to Aram - This is a message about Damascus: “The city of Damascus will be destroyed; only ruins will remain.

2.verse: People will leave the cities of Aroer. Flocks will wander freely in those empty towns, and there will be no one to bother them.

3.verse: The strong, walled cities of Israel will be destroyed. The government in Damascus will end. Those left alive of Aram will be like the glory of Israel,” says the LORD All-Powerful.

4.verse: “At that time Israel’s wealth will all be gone. Israel will be like someone who has lost much weight from sickness.

5.verse: That time will be like the grain harvest in the Valley of Rephaim. The workers cut the wheat. Then they cut the heads of grain from the plants and collect the grain.

6.verse: That time will also be like the olive harvest, when a few olives are left. Two or three olives are left in the top branches. Four or five olives are left on full branches,” says the LORD, the God of Israel.

7.verse: At that time people will look to God, their Maker; their eyes will see the Holy One of Israel.

8.verse: They will not trust the altars they have made, nor will they trust what their hands have made, not even the Asherah idols and altars.

9.verse: In that day all their strong cities will be empty. They will be like the cities the Hivites and the Amorites left when the Israelites came to take the land. Everything will be ruined.

10.verse: You have forgotten the God who saves you; you have not remembered that God is your place of safety. You plant the finest grapevines and grapevines from faraway places.

11.verse: You plant your grapevines one day and try to make them grow, and the next day you make them blossom. But at harvest time everything will be dead; a sickness will kill all the plants.

12.verse: Listen to the many people! Their crying is like the noise from the sea. Listen to the nations! Their crying is like the crashing of great waves.

13.verse: The people roar like the waves, but when God speaks harshly to them, they will run away. They will be like chaff on the hills being blown by the wind, or like tumbleweeds blown away by a storm.

14.verse: At night the people will be very frightened. Before morning, no one will be left. So our enemies will come to our land, but they will become nothing.

1.verse: God’s Message to Cush - How terrible it will be for the land beyond the rivers of Cush. It is filled with the sound of wings.

2.verse: That land sends messengers across the sea; they go on the water in boats made of reeds. Go, quick messengers, to a people who are tall and smooth-skinned, who are feared everywhere. They are a powerful nation that defeats other nations. Their land is divided by rivers.

3.verse: All you people of the world, look! Everyone who lives in the world, look! You will see a banner raised on a mountain. You will hear a trumpet sound.

4.verse: The LORD said to me, “I will quietly watch from where I live, like heat in the sunshine, like the dew in the heat of harvest time.”

5.verse: The time will come, after the flowers have bloomed and before the harvest, when new grapes will be budding and growing. The enemy will cut the plants with knives; he will cut down the vines and take them away.

6.verse: They will be left for the birds of the mountains and for the wild animals. Birds will feed on them all summer, and wild animals will eat them that winter.”

7.verse: At that time a gift will be brought to the LORD All-Powerful from the people who are tall and smooth-skinned, who are feared everywhere. They are a powerful nation that defeats other nations. Their land is divided by rivers. These gifts will be brought to the place of the LORD All-Powerful, to Mount Zion.

1.verse: God’s Message to Egypt - This is a message about Egypt: Look, the LORD is coming on a fast cloud to enter Egypt. The idols of Egypt will tremble before him, and Egypt’s courage will melt away.

2.verse: The LORD says, “I will cause the Egyptians to fight against themselves. People will fight with their relatives; neighbors will fight neighbors; cities will fight cities; kingdoms will fight kingdoms.

3.verse: The Egyptians will be afraid, and I will ruin their plans. They will ask advice from their idols and spirits of the dead, from their mediums and fortune-tellers.”

4.verse: The Lord GOD All-Powerful says, “I will hand Egypt over to a hard master, and a powerful king will rule over them.”

5.verse: The sea will become dry, and the water will disappear from the Nile River.

6.verse: The canals will stink; the streams of Egypt will decrease and dry up. All the water plants will rot;

7.verse: all the plants along the banks of the Nile will die. Even the planted fields by the Nile will dry up, blow away, and disappear.

8.verse: The fishermen, all those who catch fish from the Nile, will groan and cry; those who fish in the Nile will be sad.

9.verse: All the people who make cloth from flax will be sad, and those who weave linen will lose hope.

10.verse: Those who weave cloth will be broken. All those who work for money will be sad.

11.verse: The officers of the city of Zoan are fools; the wise men who advise the king of Egypt give wrong advice. How can you say to him, ‘I am wise’? How can you say, ‘I am from the old family of the kings’?

12.verse: Egypt, where are your wise men? Let them show you what the LORD All-Powerful has planned for Egypt.

13.verse: The officers of Zoan have been fooled; the leaders of Memphis have believed false things. So the leaders of Egypt lead that nation the wrong way.

14.verse: The LORD has made the leaders confused. They have led Egypt to wander in the wrong ways, like drunk people stumbling in their own vomit.

15.verse: There is nothing Egypt can do; no one there can help.

16.verse: In that day the Egyptians will be like women. They will be afraid of the LORD All-Powerful, because he will raise his hand to strike them down.

17.verse: The land of Judah will bring fear to Egypt. Anyone there who hears the name Judah will be afraid, because the LORD All-Powerful has planned terrible things for them.

18.verse: At that time five cities in Egypt will speak Hebrew, the language of Canaan, and they will promise to be loyal to the LORD All-Powerful. One of these cities will be named the City of Destruction.

19.verse: At that time there will be an altar for the LORD in the middle of Egypt and a monument to the LORD at the border of Egypt.

20.verse: This will be a sign and a witness to the LORD All-Powerful in the land of Egypt. When the people cry to the LORD for help, he will send someone to save and defend them. He will rescue them from those who hurt them.

21.verse: So the LORD will show himself to the Egyptians, and then they will know he is the LORD. They will worship God and offer many sacrifices. They will make promises to the LORD and will keep them.

22.verse: The LORD will punish the Egyptians, but then he will heal them. They will come back to the LORD, and he will listen to their prayers and heal them.

23.verse: At that time there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrians will go to Egypt, and the Egyptians will go to Assyria. The Egyptians and Assyrians will worship God together.

24.verse: At that time Israel, Assyria, and Egypt will join together, which will be a blessing for the earth.

25.verse: The LORD All-Powerful will bless them, saying, “Egypt, you are my people. Assyria, I made you. Israel, I own you. You are all blessed!”

1.verse: Assyria Will Defeat Egypt and Cush - Sargon king of Assyria sent a military commander to Ashdod to attack that city. So the commander attacked and captured it.

2.verse: Then the LORD spoke through Isaiah son of Amoz, saying, “Take the rough cloth off your body, and take your sandals off your feet.” So Isaiah obeyed and walked around naked and barefoot.

3.verse: Then the LORD said, “Isaiah my servant has walked around naked and barefoot for three years as a sign against Egypt and Cush.

4.verse: The king of Assyria will carry away prisoners from Egypt and Cush. Old people and young people will be led away naked and barefoot, with their buttocks bare. So the Egyptians will be shamed.

5.verse: People who looked to Cush for help will be afraid, and those who were amazed by Egypt’s glory will be shamed.

6.verse: People who live near the sea will say, ‘Look at those countries. We trusted them to help us. We ran to them so they would save us from the king of Assyria. So how will we be able to escape?’”

1.verse: God’s Message to Babylon - This is a message about the Desert by the Sea: Disaster is coming from the desert like wind blowing in the south. It is coming from a terrible country.

2.verse: I have seen a terrible vision. I see traitors turning against you and people taking your wealth. Elam, attack the people! Media, surround the city and attack it! I will bring an end to the pain the city causes.

3.verse: I saw those terrible things, and now I am in pain; my pains are like the pains of giving birth. What I hear makes me very afraid; what I see causes me to shake with fear.

4.verse: I am worried, and I am shaking with fear. My pleasant evening has become a night of fear.

5.verse: They set the table; they spread the rugs; they eat and drink. Leaders, stand up. Prepare the shields for battle!

6.verse: The Lord said to me, “Go, place a lookout for the city and have him report what he sees.

7.verse: If he sees chariots and teams of horses, donkeys, or camels, he should pay very close attention.”

8.verse: Then the lookout called out, “My master, each day I stand in the watchtower watching; every night I have been on guard.

9.verse: Look, I see a man coming in a chariot with a team of horses.” The man gives back the answer, “Babylon has fallen. It has fallen! All the statues of her gods lie broken on the ground.”

10.verse: My people are crushed like grain on the threshing floor. My people, I tell you what I have heard from the LORD All-Powerful, from the God of Israel.

11.verse: God’s Message to Edom - This is a message about Dumah: Someone calls to me from Edom, “Watchman, how much of the night is left? Watchman, how much longer will it be night?”

12.verse: The watchman answers, “Morning is coming, but then night will come again. If you have something to ask, then come back and ask.”

13.verse: God’s Message to Arabia - This is a message about Arabia: A group of traders from Dedan spent the night near some trees in Arabia.

14.verse: They gave water to thirsty travelers; the people of Tema gave food to those who were escaping.

15.verse: They were running from swords, from swords ready to kill, from bows ready to shoot, from a hard battle.

16.verse: This is what the Lord said to me: “In one year all the glory of the country of Kedar will be gone. (This is a year as a hired helper counts time.)

17.verse: At that time only a few of the archers, the soldiers of Kedar, will be left alive.” The LORD, the God of Israel, has spoken.

1.verse: God’s Message to Jerusalem - This is a message about the Valley of Vision: What is wrong with you people? Why are you on your roofs?

2.verse: This city was a very busy city, full of noise and wild parties. Now your people have been killed, but not with swords, nor did they die in battle.

3.verse: All your leaders ran away together, but they have been captured without using a bow. All you who were captured tried to run away before the enemy came.

4.verse: So I say, “Don’t look at me. Let me cry loudly. Don’t hurry to comfort me about the destruction of Jerusalem.”

5.verse: The Lord GOD All-Powerful has chosen a special day of riots and confusion. People will trample each other in the Valley of Vision. The city walls will be knocked down, and the people will cry out to the mountain.

6.verse: The soldiers from Elam will gather their arrows and their chariots and men on horses. Kir will prepare their shields.

7.verse: Your nicest valleys will be filled with chariots. Horsemen will be ordered to guard the gates of the city.

8.verse: The walls protecting Judah will fall. At that time the people of Jerusalem depended on the weapons kept at the Palace of the Forest.

9.verse: You saw that the walls of Jerusalem had many cracks that needed repairing. You stored up water in the lower pool.

10.verse: You counted the houses of Jerusalem, and you tore down houses to repair the walls with their stones.

11.verse: You made a pool between the two walls to save water from the old pool, but you did not trust the God who made these things; you did not respect the One who planned them long ago.

12.verse: The Lord GOD All-Powerful told the people to cry and be sad, to shave their heads and wear rough cloth.

13.verse: But look, the people are happy and are having wild parties. They kill the cattle and the sheep; they eat the food and drink the wine. They say, “Let us eat and drink, because tomorrow we will die.”

14.verse: The LORD All-Powerful said to me: “You people will die before this guilt is forgiven.” The Lord GOD All-Powerful said this.

15.verse: God’s Message to Shebna - This is what the Lord GOD All-Powerful says: “Go to this servant Shebna, the manager of the palace.

16.verse: Say to him, ‘What are you doing here? Who said you could cut out a tomb for yourself here? Why are you preparing your tomb in a high place? Why are you carving out a tomb from the rock?

17.verse: Look, mighty one! The LORD will throw you away. He will take firm hold of you

18.verse: and roll you tightly into a ball and throw you into another country. There you will die, and there your fine chariots will remain. You are a disgrace to your master’s house.

19.verse: I will force you out of your important job, and you will be thrown down from your important place.’

20.verse: “At that time I will call for my servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah.

21.verse: I will take your robe and put it on him and give him your belt. I will hand over to him the important job you have, and he will be like a father to the people of Jerusalem and the family of Judah.

22.verse: I will put the key to the house of David around his neck. If he opens a door, no one will be able to close it; if he closes a door, no one will be able to open it.

23.verse: He will be like an honored chair in his father’s house. I will make him strong like a peg that is hammered into a strong board.

24.verse: All the honored and important things of his family will depend on him; all the adults and little children will depend on him. They will be like bowls and jars hanging on him.

25.verse: “At that time,” says the LORD All-Powerful, “the peg hammered into the strong board will weaken. It will break and fall, and everything hanging on it will be destroyed.” The LORD says this.

1.verse: God’s Message to Lebanon - This is a message about Tyre: You trading ships, cry! The houses and harbor of Tyre are destroyed. This news came to the ships from the land of Cyprus.

2.verse: Be silent, you who live on the island of Tyre; you merchants of Sidon, be silent. Sailors have made you rich.

3.verse: They traveled the sea to bring grain from Egypt; the sailors of Tyre brought grain from the Nile Valley and sold it to other nations.

4.verse: Sidon, be ashamed. Strong city of the sea, be ashamed, because the sea says: “I have not felt the pain of giving birth; I have not reared young men or women.”

5.verse: Egypt will hear the news about Tyre, and it will make Egypt hurt with sorrow.

6.verse: You ships should return to Tarshish. You people living near the sea should be sad.

7.verse: Look at your once happy city! Look at your old, old city! People from that city have traveled far away to live.

8.verse: Who planned Tyre’s destruction? Tyre made others rich. Its merchants were treated like princes, and its traders were greatly respected.

9.verse: It was the LORD All-Powerful who planned this. He decided to make these proud people unimportant; he decided to disgrace those who were greatly respected.

10.verse: Go through your land, people of Tarshish, like the Nile goes through Egypt. There is no harbor for you now!

11.verse: The LORD has stretched his hand over the sea and made its kingdoms tremble. He commands that Canaan’s strong, walled cities be destroyed.

12.verse: He said, “Sidon, you will not rejoice any longer, because you are destroyed. Even if you cross the sea to Cyprus, you will not find a place to rest.”

13.verse: Look at the land of the Babylonians; it is not a country now. Assyria has made it a place for wild animals. Assyria built towers to attack it; the soldiers took all the treasures from its cities, and they turned it into ruins.

14.verse: So be sad, you trading ships, because your strong city is destroyed.

15.verse: At that time people will forget about Tyre for seventy years, which is the length of a king’s life. After seventy years, Tyre will be like the prostitute in this song:

16.verse: “Oh woman, you are forgotten. Take your harp and walk through the city. Play your harp well. Sing your song often. Then people will remember you.”

17.verse: After seventy years the LORD will deal with Tyre, and it will again have trade. It will be like a prostitute for all the nations of the earth.

18.verse: The profits will be saved for the LORD. Tyre will not keep the money she earns but will give them to the people who serve the LORD, so they will have plenty of food and nice clothes.

1.verse: The Lord Will Punish the World - Look! The LORD will destroy the earth and leave it empty; he will ruin the surface of the land and scatter its people.

2.verse: At that time the same thing will happen to everyone: to common people and priests, to slaves and masters, to women slaves and their women masters, to buyers and sellers, to those who borrow and those who lend, to bankers and those who owe the bank.

3.verse: The earth will be completely empty. The wealth will all be taken, because the LORD has commanded it.

4.verse: The earth will dry up and die; the world will grow weak and die; the great leaders in this land will become weak.

5.verse: The people of the earth have ruined it, because they do not follow God’s teachings or obey God’s laws or keep their agreement with God that was to last forever.

6.verse: So a curse will destroy the earth. The people of the world are guilty, so they will be burned up; only a few will be left.

7.verse: The new wine will be bad, and the grapevines will die. People who were happy will be sad.

8.verse: The happy music of the tambourines will end. The happy sounds of wild parties will stop. The joyful music from the harps will end.

9.verse: People will no longer sing while they drink their wine. The beer will taste bitter to those who drink it.

10.verse: The ruined city will be empty, and people will hide behind closed doors.

11.verse: People in the streets will ask for wine, but joy will have turned to sadness; all the happiness will have left.

12.verse: The city will be left in ruins, and its gates will be smashed to pieces.

13.verse: This is what will happen all over the earth and to all the nations. The earth will be like an olive tree after the harvest or like the few grapes left on a vine after harvest.

14.verse: The people shout for joy. From the west they praise the greatness of the LORD.

15.verse: People in the east, praise the LORD. People in the islands of the sea, praise the name of the LORD, the God of Israel.

16.verse: We hear songs from every part of the earth praising God, the Righteous One. But I said, “I am dying! I am dying! How terrible it will be for me! Traitors turn against people; with their dishonesty, they turn against people.”

17.verse: There are terrors, holes, and traps for the people of the earth.

18.verse: Anyone who tries to escape from the sound of terror will fall into a hole. Anyone who climbs out of the hole will be caught in a trap. The clouds in the sky will pour out rain, and the foundations of the earth will shake.

19.verse: The earth will be broken up; the earth will split open; the earth will shake violently.

20.verse: The earth will stumble around like someone who is drunk; it will shake like a hut in a storm. Its sin is like a heavy weight on its back; it will fall and never rise again.

21.verse: At that time the LORD will punish the powers in the sky above and the rulers on earth below.

22.verse: They will be gathered together like prisoners thrown into a dungeon; they will be shut up in prison. After much time they will be punished.

23.verse: The moon will be embarrassed, and the sun will be ashamed, because the LORD All-Powerful will rule as king on Mount Zion in Jerusalem. Jerusalem’s leaders will see his greatness.

1.verse: A Song of Praise to God - LORD, you are my God. I honor you and praise you, because you have done amazing things. You have always done what you said you would do; you have done what you planned long ago.

2.verse: You have made the city a pile of rocks and have destroyed her walls. The city our enemies built with strong walls is gone; it will never be built again.

3.verse: People from powerful nations will honor you; cruel people from strong cities will fear you.

4.verse: You protect the poor; you protect the helpless when they are in danger. You are like a shelter from storms, like shade that protects them from the heat. The cruel people attack like a rainstorm beating against the wall,

5.verse: like the heat in the desert. But you, God, stop their violent attack. As a cloud cools a hot day, you silence the songs of those who have no mercy.

6.verse: God’s Banquet for His Servants - The LORD All-Powerful will prepare a feast on this mountain for all people. It will be a feast with all the best food and wine, the finest meat and wine.

7.verse: On this mountain God will destroy the veil that covers all nations, the veil that stretches over all peoples;

8.verse: he will destroy death forever. The Lord GOD will wipe away every tear from every face. He will take away the shame of his people from the earth. The LORD has spoken.

9.verse: At that time people will say, “Our God is doing this! We have waited for him, and he has come to save us. This is the LORD. We waited for him, so we will rejoice and be happy when he saves us.”

10.verse: The LORD will protect Jerusalem, but he will crush our enemy Moab like straw that is trampled down in the manure.

11.verse: They will spread their arms in it like a person who is swimming. But God will bring down their pride, and all the clever things they have made will mean nothing.

12.verse: Moab’s high walls protect them, but God will destroy these walls. He will throw them down to the ground, even to the dust.

1.verse: A Song of Praise to God - At that time people will sing this song in Judah: We have a strong city. God protects us with its strong walls and defenses.

2.verse: Open the gates, and the good people will enter, those who follow God.

3.verse: You, LORD, give true peace to those who depend on you, because they trust you.

4.verse: So, trust the LORD always, because he is our Rock forever.

5.verse: He will destroy the proud city, and he will punish the people living there. He will bring that high city down to the ground and throw it down into the dust.

6.verse: Then those who were hurt by the city will walk on its ruins; those who were made poor by the city will trample it under their feet.

7.verse: The path of life is level for those who are right with God; LORD, you make the way of life smooth for those people.

8.verse: But, LORD, we are waiting for your way of justice. Our souls want to remember you and your name.

9.verse: My soul wants to be with you at night, and my spirit wants to be with you at the dawn of every day. When your way of justice comes to the land, people of the world will learn the right way of living.

10.verse: Evil people will not learn to do good even if you show them kindness. They will continue doing evil, even if they live in a good world; they never see the LORD’s greatness.

11.verse: LORD, you are ready to punish those people, but they do not see that. Show them your strong love for your people. Then those who are evil will be ashamed. Burn them in the fire you have prepared for your enemies.

12.verse: LORD, all our success is because of what you have done, so give us peace.

13.verse: LORD, our God, other masters besides you have ruled us, but we honor only you.

14.verse: Those masters are now dead; their ghosts will not rise from death. You punished and destroyed them and erased any memory of them.

15.verse: LORD, you multiplied the number of your people; you multiplied them and brought honor to yourself. You made the borders of the land wide.

16.verse: LORD, people remember you when they are in trouble; they say quiet prayers to you when you punish them.

17.verse: LORD, when we are with you, we are like a woman giving birth to a baby; she cries and has pain from the birth.

18.verse: In the same way, we had pain. We gave birth, but only to wind. We don’t bring salvation to the land or make new people for the world.

19.verse: Your people have died, but they will live again; their bodies will rise from death. You who lie in the ground, wake up and be happy! The dew covering you is like the dew of a new day; the ground will give birth to the dead.

20.verse: Judgment: Reward or Punishment - My people, go into your rooms and shut your doors behind you. Hide in your rooms for a short time until God’s anger is finished.

21.verse: The LORD will leave his place to punish the people of the world for their sins. The earth will show the blood of the people who have been killed; it will not cover the dead any longer.

1.verse: At that time the LORD will punish Leviathan, the gliding snake. He will punish Leviathan, the coiled snake, with his great and hard and powerful sword. He will kill the monster in the sea.

2.verse: At that time people will sing about the pleasant vineyard.

3.verse: “I, the LORD, will care for that vineyard; I will water it at the right time. No one will hurt it, because I will guard it day and night.

4.verse: I am not angry. If anyone builds a wall of thornbushes in war, I will march to it and burn it.

5.verse: But if anyone comes to me for safety and wants to make peace with me, he should come and make peace with me.”

6.verse: In the days to come, the people of Jacob will be like a plant with good roots; Israel will grow like a plant beginning to bloom. Then the world will be filled with their children.

7.verse: The Lord Will Send Israel Away - The LORD has not hurt his people as he hurt their enemies; his people have not been killed like those who tried to kill them.

8.verse: He will settle his argument with Israel by sending it far away. Like a hot desert wind, he will drive it away.

9.verse: This is how Israel’s guilt will be forgiven; this is how its sins will be taken away: Israel will crush the rocks of the altar to dust, and no statues or altars will be left standing for the Asherah idols.

10.verse: At that time the strong, walled city will be empty like a desert. Calves will eat grass there. They will lie down there and eat leaves from the branches.

11.verse: The limbs will become dry and break off, so women will use them for firewood. The people refuse to understand, so God will not comfort them; their Maker will not be kind to them.

12.verse: At that time the LORD will begin gathering his people one by one from the Euphrates River to the brook of Egypt. He will separate them from others as grain is separated from chaff.

13.verse: Many of my people are now lost in Assyria. Some have run away to Egypt. But at that time a great trumpet will be blown, and all those people will come and worship the LORD on that holy mountain in Jerusalem.

1.verse: Warnings to Israel - How terrible it will be for Samaria, the pride of Israel’s drunken people! That beautiful crown of flowers is just a dying plant set on a hill above a rich valley where drunkards live.

2.verse: Look, the Lord has someone who is strong and powerful. Like a storm of hail and strong wind, like a sudden flood of water pouring over the country, he will throw Samaria down to the ground.
